Fig. 10 N-doped graphene as an efficient electrocatalyst for lithium-thionyl chloride batteries Bimei Li a Zhongzhi Yuan a ⁎ Ying Xu b Jincheng Liu b ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Environment, South China Normal University, Guangzhou 510006, China School of Chemistry and Environment South China Normal University Guangzhou 510006 China b EVE Energy Co. Ltd, Huizhou 516006, China EVE Energy Co. Ltd Huizhou 516006 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Nitrogen-doped graphene (N-G) catalysts, synthesized by mixing nitrogen from urea with graphene and subsequent high temperature pyrolysis, have significantly increased the discharge voltage and capacity of Li/SOCl2 batteries. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves and the battery discharge profiles demonstrated that the synthesis temperature of the N-G catalysts had a significant effect on the catalytic performance. A comparison of the catalytic performance of the N-G catalysts at various synthesis temperatures (600°C, 800°C, 900°C) exhibited the following results: N-G-900>N-G-800>N-G-600. However, the X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and cyclic voltammetry results suggest that the N elements incorporated in the molecular structure of graphene in the form of a “pyridinic-N” cyclic substructure at high synthesis temperatures is the critical factor in enhancing the catalytic performance of graphene, rather than “high synthesis temperatures” alone. Keywords Lithium-thionyl chloride battery Graphene Nitrogen doping Electrocatalyst 1 Introduction It has been reported that macrocycles induce high catalytic activity in lithium-thionyl chloride (Li/SOCl2) batteries [1–4]. In particular, graphene is widely presumed to exhibit greater catalytic activity in batteries, largely because the π-electron conjugation in its structure, formed by the sp2-hybridized carbon atoms, resembles the structure of macrocycles. However, experiments have revealed nonsignificant catalytic activity of graphene in Li/SOCl2 batteries, most likely because the graphene is a gapless semiconductor, and its tightly bound electronic structure may inhibit the formation of catalytic active sites. N-doped graphene (N-G) has been developed as an efficient catalyst in fuel cells. The N-doping was obtained by the pyrolysis of a mixture of carbon material and an N-containing precursor [5,6]. Other studies [7,8] indicate that high temperature pyrolysis, used for nitrogen doping, introduced structural defects and then created new active sites. To the best of our knowledge, the catalytic activity of N-doped graphene has not be studied for use in Li/SOCl2 batteries. We plan to introduce nitrogen into the molecular structure of graphene to form an N-macrocycle-like substructure, given that transition metal macrocyclic compounds have revealed catalytic activity in Li/SOCl2 batteries [1–4]. However, these previous studies have shown that the activity site is based on an N-macrocycle coordinated to a transition metal atom in the structure, which is not the case in our system. Moreover, the synthesis of macrocyclic compounds is highly complicated and the raw materials, such as the cyanides, are toxic and expensive. Based on these studies, we have incorporated nitrogen into graphene (noting that nitrogen has a higher electronegativity than carbon) to break the carbon sp2-hybridized structure and the electroneutrality of the graphene, in order to enhance the electron mobility. Subsequently, the modified electronic structure of graphene formed an N-heterocyclic structure that improved the catalytic performance of Li/SOCl2 batteries. In addition, the process for synthesizing N-doped graphene was easier, safer and more environmentally friendly than the synthesis process of other macrocyclic compounds. Furthermore, in contrast to macrocyclic compound dissolution, N-doped graphene can be mixed with acetylene black, due to its insolubility in the electrolyte, to ensure catalyst stabilty in the porous cathode. Finally, this study has provided a new alternative approach for synthesizing novel catalysts in Li/SOCl2 batteries, which has widespread significance for alternative energy and power sources. 2 Experimental 2.1 N-G catalyst synthesis First, 300mg of graphene (BET≈300m2 g−1, particle size 2–3μm, Fe<30ppm; Cabot Corporation, USA) and 300mg of urea (analytical reagent; Shantou Dahao Fine Chemical Co., Ltd., China) were mixed in 40mL of anhydrous ethanol (analytical reagent; Tianjin Zhiyuan Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd, China). The resulting mixture was thoroughly mixed via ultrasonication at 1000W for 3h, and the solvent was subsequently evaporated by heating. After the mixture was vacuum-dried at 80°C for 10h, the derived powder was grounded, and pyrolyzed for 1h in a tubelar furnace under Ar atmosphere at 600°C, 800°C, 900°C, respectively (temperature increment=5°Cmin−1), and finally cooled to yield the N-doped graphene (N-G) catalysts N-G-600, N-G-800, and N-G-900. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The morphology of the sample catalysts was examined using an FEI Nova NanoSEM 450 scanning electron microscope (SEM). The structural analysis of the samples was conducted on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using a Cu Kα radiation source (λ=0.15406nm). A scanning range of 2θ=10–80°, a voltage of 40kV and a current of 40mA. Next, a Raman spectroscopy (Renishaw inVia Raman Spectroscope, UK) was used to test the samples at an excitation wavelength λ of 514.5nm. Finally, a thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA 4000; Perkin Elmer, USA) was used to perform a thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the samples in air with a linear heating rate of 10Kmin−1 from room temperature to 800°C. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of the samples were acquired with a Thermo Fisher Scientific ESCALAB 250 spectrometer fitted with an Al Ka (hv=1486.6eV) 150W X-ray source. 2.3 Electrochemical testing 2.3.1 Cyclic voltammetry tests An electrochemical workstation (CHI600e; CH Instruments), equipped with a three-electrode electrochemical test system, was employed for the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curve measurements, in a dry atmosphere, at a dew point temperature of −60°C, a potential scanning range between 5.0 and 1.0V (vs. Li/Li+) and a scanning speed of 100mVs−1. This system used metal lithium as both the counter and reference electrodes, a catalyst-coated glassy carbon electrode as the working electrode, and 1.5molL−1 LiAlCl4/SOCl2 as the electrolyte (the LiAlCl4 was synthesized in our laboratory, and the SOCl2 was obtained from LANXESS, and distilled before use). Before use, the glassy carbon electrode (d=1mm; Tianjin Ida Tech Co., Ltd.) was polished to a mirror surface using 0.05μm alumina powder on deerskin, cleaned in an ultrasonicator for 4min, and later dried at 80°C for 12h. The catalyst coating for the working electrode was prepared by first adding 4mg of the N-G catalyst to 4mL of anhydrous ethanol. Next, this mixture was uniformly dispersed with ultrasonication at 1000W for 30min. Finally, the electrode was coated with 20μL of catalyst-containing uniform dispersion (solution), vacuum dried for 30min, and stored in a dry glove box at a dew point temperature of −60°C. 2.3.2 Battery discharge tests First, 100mg of acetylene carbon black (50% compressed; Denka, Japan), a specified amount of N-G catalyst, 8wt% polytetrafluoroethylene emulsion (PTFE; with a solid content of 60wt%; Dakin, Japan), and a specified amount of anhydrous ethanol were mixed, and then dried in an air-drying oven for 2h at 80°C, plus an additional 10min at 250°C. Next, a double-roll mill was used to press the carbon material into separate carbon plates to a thickness of 1±0.1mm. These plates were pasted on a nickel mesh. Finally, the plate-pasted mesh was cut into several 13×16mm pieces as battery cathode materials, which were subsequently vacuum-dried at 180°C for 12h. Li/SOCl2 batteries were assembled in a dry glove box at a dew point temperature of −60°C by inserting metal lithium plates (anode) and catalyst-containing carbon plates (cathode) into 1.5molL−1 LiAlCl4/SOCl2 electrolyte. The battery was placed in a dry glove box for 2h and then discharged to 2V with a current density of 25mA cm−2 (discharge device: Battery Test System, Newware, China). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst morphology and structure Fig. 1 displays four scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the samples, all of which exhibited sheet-like morphologies. No morphological changes were observed in the N-doped materials at various temperatures. X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectroscopy revealed that graphene exhibited a sharp diffraction peak at 2θ=26° and a weak diffraction peak at 2θ=43° (Fig. 2 ), both are characteristic graphene peaks [9]. The sharp diffraction peak at 2θ=26° indicates the good crystallinity in the graphene structure. The N-doped graphene catalysts (including N-G-600, N-G-800, or N-G-900) also showed diffraction peaks at 2θ=26° and 43°, suggesting that graphene still retained its original structural properties after the N insertion. However, the intensity of the peak was significantly reduced, indicating that the crystallinity of the N-G was inferior to that of the graphene as a result of structural damage caused by the N-doping. In addition, N-G-600 presented a weaker diffraction peak at 2θ=26° than did N-G-800 or N-G-900, possibly because the graphene was covered with elements produced by the thermal decomposition of urea at 600°C. Raman spectroscopy was aslo used to further analyze the structure of these three N-G catalysts (Fig. 3 ). Graphene and all three N-G catalysts exhibited two prominent bands: the D-band (at approximately 1346nm) and the G-band (at approximately 1575nm). The D-band was attributed to the structural defects or partial disorderliness in the carbon material, whereas the G-band indicated an ordered sp2-bonded carbon structure. The ratio of the intensity of the D-band to that of the G-band (I D/I G) refers to the degree of disorder in carbon [10]. The I D/I G values of graphene, N-G-600, N-G-800, and N-G-900 were 0.367, 0.217, 0.459, and 0.528, respectively. Clearly, the I D/I G values of both N-G-800 and N-G-900 were higher than that of graphene and increased as the synthesis temperature rose. This result suggests two possible reasons for the increased degree of disorder in graphene. First, nitrogen atoms have been inserted into the graphene structure. Second, the increasing synthesis temperature disrupted the orderliness in the structure. However, the I D/I G value of graphene (0.367) was higher than that of N-G-600 (0.217) most likely because N-G-600 was covered with N-containing elements from the thermal decomposition of urea. 3.2 Electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts 3.2.1 Cyclic voltammetry analysis When the glassy carbon electrode was coated with acetylene black (AB) instead of a catalyst, the cyclic voltammetry curve (Fig. 4 ) depicts two strong peaks at 3.426V and 2.616V. This finding is indicative of a reduction reaction in SOCl2 involving the two steps, expressed in electrochemical reaction Eqs. (1) and (2) [11,12]. The high current peak at 2.616V and the low current peak at 3.426V suggest that Eq. (1) is the rate-controlling step and Eq. (2) is the fast reaction step for the reductive reaction of SOCl2 [13]. There was no relevant oxidation peak in the reverse scanning process, suggesting that the reduction of SOCl2 is irreversible. The result agrees with previous studies [14]. (1) S O C l 2 + e → 1 2 S C l 2 + 1 2 S O 2 + C l − (2) 1 2 S C l 2 + e → 1 2 S + C l − There was no change in the peak potential and the current of graphene compared with the AB, indicating that graphene has the same catalytic effect on the reduction of SOCl2 as AB. However, the peak potentials of the N-G-800 (2.714V, 0.4mA) and N-G-900 (2.735V, 0.55mA) curves moved in a positive direction, which resulted in a decrease in the overpotential. In addition, their peak currents were intensified at 2.616V, which corresponds to a reduction of SOCl2. This further demonstrated that N-G-800 and N-G-900 yielded a favorable catalytic effect for the reduction reaction [15,16]. Good electrocatalytic activity was achieved because of an efficient acceleration in the reaction speed of the rate-controlling step [Eq. (1)] and by the shift of the reduction potential for SOCl2 in a positive direction [11]. A comparison of the catalytic performance of the N-G catalysts at various synthesis temperatures showed the following results: N-G-900>N-G-800>N-G-600. 3.2.2 Battery discharge performance The electrocatalytic activity of catalysts is reflected by battery discharge voltage, time and capacity (C). And the discharge capacity (C) of a battery is calculated using C = ∫ I d t = ∫ U / R e d t = 1 / R e ∑ U Δ t , where R e =external resistance, U =discharge voltage, and Δ t =discharge time [11]. Given that the discharge capacity is positively correlated with the discharge voltage and time, the capacity of the battery reflects the electrocatalytic activity of N-G catalysts. To further confirm the effect of N-G catalysts on Li/SOCl2 batteries, 1wt% N-G catalysts were added to the carbon cathode during the assembly of the aforementioned batteries. Their discharge profiles are shown in Fig. 5 . The N-G catalysts discharge voltage and capacity increased more significantly in comparison to AB (1095.06mAh g−1). In addition, the discharge capacities of N-G-800 and N-G-900 were significantly higher than that of N-G-600 (1164.78mAh g−1). Additionally, the discharge capacities of N-G-600, N-G-800 (1230mAh g−1), and N-G-900 (1534mAh g−1) were higher than that of AB by 69.72mAh g−1, 134.94mAh g−1, and 438.94mAh g−1, respectively, indicating a strong catalytic effect of the N-G catalysts on SOCl2 reduction. Of all N-G catalysts, N-G-900 exhibited the highest catalytic performance. As the content of the N-G-900 catalyst increased, the discharge capacity of the batteries increased. However, the discharge capacity decreased when the catalyst was at 20wt%. This indicates that the catalytic effect of N-G-900 on SOCl2 is related to the content of N-G-900. Consequently, an excess of N-G-900 may block the pores of the carbon cathode hindering SOCl2 adsorption (Fig. 6 ). The results from the CV curves and the battery discharge profiles revealed that the catalytic activity of N-G in the reduction of SOCl2 is positively correlated with the N-G synthesis temperature. Additionally, the catalytic activity of N-G-600 for SOCl2 reduction was nonsignificant compared to the substantial catalytic activity of N-G-800 and N-G-900. An analysis of the N-G-600 XRD patterns and Raman spectra indicated that the N-containing materials from the thermal decomposition of urea were located on the surface of the graphene, rather than inserted into the molecular structure of graphene, and thus did not affect its electron structure, However, N-G-800 and N-G-900 exert a favorable catalytic effect on the reduction of SOCl2, because the N-atoms inserted into the molecular structure of graphene, form macrocycle-like substructures that create new activity sites. Additionally, the higher catalytic performance of N-G-900 compared to N-G-800 may result from a variation in the N-macrocyclic structure. 3.3 Catalytic effects of N-heteroatoms on SOCl2 reduction The CV curves and the battery discharge profiles showed that N-G-900 produced the highest catalytic effect on SOCl2, indicating that the synthesis temperature had a significant effect on the catalytic activity of the N-G catalysts. However, whether N-doping was a crucial factor in improving the catalytic performance of graphene remained uncertain. To determine the role of N-doping in increasing the catalytic activity of graphene, pure geaphene was pyrolyzed at 900°C for 1h to derive G-900. A comparison of the XRD patterns of graphene, G-900, and N-G-900 revealed that the peak intensity of G-900 was significantly stronger than that of N-G-900 but weaker than that of pure graphene (Fig. 2). This finding indicated that the high pyrolysis temperature destroyed the graphene structure to a limited degree, thereby increasing the number of defects, and that N-doping caused further damage to the structure, shown by a diminishing peak intensity (i.e., crystallinity). A comparison of the Raman spectra for G-900, N-G-900, and graphene showed that N-G-900 had a higher I D/I G (0.528) value than both G-900 (0.489) and graphene (0.367) (Fig. 3), indicating that the high pyrolysis temperature damaged the graphene structure, thereby increased its disorderliness. The TGA results at 100°C show a 0% weight loss for N-G-900 and G-900, and a slight 0.27% weight loss for graphene, indicating that the graphene contained a small quantity of water. At 300–600°C, the weight losses for N-G-900, G-900, and graphene were 1.88%, 2.92%, and 4.22%, respectively. The high weight loss of graphene in this temperature range was attributed to the pyrolysis of the material’s oxygen functional groups such as hydroxyl or carboxyl. At 600–800°C, N-G-900, G-900, and graphene indicated weight losses of 19.66%, 16.34%, and 13.12%, respectively. The higher weight loss of N-G-900 compared with G-900 indicated that the nitrogen doped in graphene released NO2 and NO. The difference in weight loss of N-G-900 and G-900 at 600–800°C also revealed that N atoms had inserted into graphene. In addition, the higher weight loss of G-900 compared with graphene indicated that the high pyrolysis temperature caused a certain degree of damage to its graphitic structure, thereby reducing its stability. In the range of room temperature to 800°C, the weight loss of N-G-900 was greatest, followed by G-900 and then graphene, revealing a decline in the thermal stability of N-G. In summary, the XRD, Raman, and TGA results sufficiently proved that high temperatures damaged the graphene structures and that N-doping caused even further damage to those structures, thereby increasing N-G disorderliness and promoting the formation of catalytic active sites (Fig. 7 ). To analyze the catalytic effects of structural changes in graphene on SOCl2 reduction, a CV test was conducted on N-G-900 and G-900. The results (Fig. 4) show that G-900 exhibited a peak potential of 2.656V and a current of 0.482mA, indicating a slightly higher catalytic activity than both AB and graphene but lower than that of N-G-900 (2.735V, 0.55mA). The slight increase in the catalytic activity of pyrolyzed graphene (at 900°C) was observed because of the near-edge structural damage of the material, which promoted adsorption and electron transfer in SOCl2. In addition, N-doping further heightened the catalytic activity of graphene; in particular, the peak potentials of the N-G catalysts clearly shifted in the positive direction as a result of damage caused by the doping of the graphene structure. Furthermore, the high electronegativity of the N atoms affected the electronic structure of the adjacent C atoms, and thus induced a charge redistribution. The redistribution created a positive charge ( C δ + ) on the C atoms which enhanced SOCl2 adsorption and lowered the SOCl2 reduction potential [17,18]. Therefore, graphene doped with nitrogen, can achieve a significant catalytic effect on SOCl2 reduction, regardless of the doping amount. 3.4 Catalytic mechanism of N-G-900 in SOCl2 reduction XPS was used to measure the variation in N content at various synthesis temperatures and in various N environments. An examination of the XPS spectra of N-G-800 and N-G-900 revealed that both materials had a strong catalytic effect on SOCl2 reduction (Figs. 8 and 9 ). N-G-800 and N-G-900 contained concentrations of 0.49 at% and 0.22 at% of N, respectively, both of which declined as the synthesis temperature increased. Two nitrogen species were identified in both catalysts: pyridinic-N (398.48eV) and pyrrolic-N (400.29eV) [19]. As the synthesis temperature rose, the pyridinic-N concentration increased (53.6% in N-G-800<87.1% in N-G-900), and the pyrrolic-N concentration decreased (46.4% in N-G-800>13.9% in N-G-900), indicating a greater instability and partial decomposition of pyrrolic-N, with the rising temperature. This finding also suggested that the type of N-substructure in graphene, rather than the N concentration, affected the N-G catalytic performance. Thus, the active sites in N-G-900 associated with the pyridinic-N substructure, were responsible for catalyzing the SOCl2 reduction. Based on the XPS results, we assert that pyridinic-N and the adjacent C atoms formed catalytic active sites in the graphene and that the catalytic process of N-G-900 in SOCl2 reduction was as follows (Fig. 10 ): (1) the O in SOCl2 adsorbs onto C δ + to form the S O C l 2 · C δ + adduct; (2) after S O C l 2 · C δ + gains an electron from N δ - , SOCI2 is reduced to 1 2 S C l 2 and the S in SCl2 adsorbs onto C δ + to form the 1 2 S C l 2 · C δ + adduct; and (3) 1 2 S C l 2 · C δ + gains an electron from N δ - to produce 1 2 S and Cl−. 4 Conclusions Graphene has a weak catalytic effect on Li/SOCl2 batteries. Although the orderliness of the graphene structure is damaged to a certain degree under thermal pyrolysis, the catalytic performance of graphene exhibited no significant increase. Only when nitrogen, in the form of a cyclic substructure comprised primarily of pyridinic-N, is incorporated into the molecular structure of graphene did the N-G catalysts effectively catalyze the reduction reaction in Li/SOCl2 batteries. In summary, the N-G catalysts containing pyridinic-N are easy to prepare and can produce significant catalytic effects. References [1] R.J. Nowak D.R. Rolison J.J. Smith S. Szpak Electrochim. coredata.dc:description: Nitrogen-doped graphene (N-G) catalysts, synthesized by mixing nitrogen from urea with graphene and subsequent high temperature pyrolysis, have significantly increased the discharge voltage and capacity of Li/SOCl2 batteries. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves and the battery discharge profiles demonstrated that the synthesis temperature of the N-G catalysts had a significant effect on the catalytic performance. A comparison of the catalytic performance of the N-G catalysts at various synthesis temperatures (600°C, 800°C, 900°C) exhibited the following results: N-G-900>N-G-800>N-G-600. However, the X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and cyclic voltammetry results suggest that the N elements incorporated in the molecular structure of graphene in the form of a “pyridinic-N” cyclic substructure at high synthesis temperatures is the critical factor in enhancing the catalytic performance of graphene, rather than “high synthesis temperatures” alone.
coredata.dc:title: N-doped graphene as an efficient electrocatalyst for lithium-thionyl chloride batteries
